abstract.text: View-based table view instances use
to identify the nib file containing the template row view. You can specify a custom row view (without any code) by associating this key with the appropriate nib name in Interface Builder.

topicSections.title: Getting and Setting Row Size Styles

inlineContent.text: Table views are displayed in scroll views. Beginning with macOS v10.7, you can use
objects (most commonly customized
objects) instead of cells for specifying rows and columns. You can still use
objects for each row and column item if you prefer.

A table view does not store its own data; it retrieves data values as needed from a data source to which it has a weak reference. You should not, therefore, directly set data values programmatically in the table view; instead, modify the values in the data source and allow the changes to be reflected in the table view. To learn about the methods that an
object uses to provide and access the contents of its data source object, see
To customize a table viewâ€™s behavior without subclassing
, use the methods defined by the

protocol. For example, the delegate supports table column management, type-to-select functionality, row selection and editing, custom tracking, and custom views for individual columns and rows. To learn more about the table view delegate, see
Itâ€™s possible that your data source methods for populating the table view may be called before
is called if the data source is specified in Interface Builder. You should defend against this by having the data sourceâ€™s
method return
for the number of rows when the data source has not yet been configured. In
, when the data source is initialized you should always call
on the table view.
Subclassing
is usually not necessary. Instead, you customize the table view using a delegate object (an object conforming to the
protocol) and a data source object (conforming to the
protocol), or by subclassing one of the following subcomponents: cells (when using
-based table views), the row cell view or the row view (when using
-based table views), the table column class, or table column header classes.
Use the
property to enable or disable the table view, which the view inherits from

. This property affects the visual appearance of the table view differently depending on whether you use a view- or a cell-based table view. When you change the propertyâ€™s value for a cell-based table view, the system manages the visual appearance of that table viewâ€™s rows, and updates them to a state that reflects the value. Because view-based table views permit complex items in their cells, itâ€™s the developerâ€™s responsibility to update each cellâ€™s appearance as appropriate.
